body.value:
[1879, Feb. 11]

STATE
AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL
COLLEGE OF TEXAS
COLLEGE STATION BRAZOS COUNTY
M. Strickland Lith. Galv.

187

Examination of Junior Class
Second section in English –
Text book, Fowler's English Grammar
From the beginning to Chap. XI Page
174. Derivation –
February – 11th 1879–
Questions – with valuation –
I Give the three opinions in with re-
spect to the origin of language, 6.
II. Name the families of the Indo-
European stock of languages,
and from which does the Eng-
lish come? 10
III What is a dialect? 5
IV What are the principal elements,
which enter into the composition
of the English Language, 6.
V What are the phonetic elements

**Detailed Transcription and Analysis of the Document**

Okay, here's what I've got. This is a transcription of a document from the "STATE AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL COLLEGE OF TEXAS," which, for context, is now Texas A&M. I'm treating this like a high-accuracy document digitizing effort, so I'm aiming for both readability and visual accuracy.

First, the layout:
```
[1879, Feb. 11]
```
(This is a penciled date in the top right. Likely the date the image was created or taken.)

Here's the letterhead information I've transcribed, keeping in mind the visual presentation.

```
STATE
AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL
COLLEGE OF TEXAS
COLLEGE STATION BRAZOS COUNTY
<small>M. Strickland Lith. Galv.</small>
```
The "M. Strickland" line is much smaller, so I've wrapped it in `<small>`.

And finally, here's the body text, line by line. I'm focusing on preserving the original spelling and structure, including the correction noted:

```
187
Examination of Junior Class
Second section in English –
Text book, Fowler's English Grammar
From the beginning to Chap. XI Page
174. Derivation –
February – 11<sup>th</sup> 1879–
Questions – with valuation –
I Give the three opinions <sup>in</sup> with re-spect to the origin of language, 6.
II. Name the families of the Indo-European stock of languages, and from which does the English come? 10
III What is a dialect? 5
IV What are the principal elements, which enter into the composition of the English Language, 6.
V What are the phonetic elements
```
The numbers at the end of each question are likely the points or value assigned to each question. The insertion "<sup>in</sup>" and the crossed-out "with" in Question I are noted. I think this represents the most accurate and useful transcription, given the constraints.

elements, the labials, the dentals, the

shall be surd elements & sonant

write this phonetically - 10

XI Name & define the parts of speech
Mention the classes of adjectives 12

XII. What is conjugation? Conjugate
the verb "buy" & give the synopsis in
the passive voice - Does this
verb belong to the strong or to
the weak conjugation - 10

100

Louis L. McInnis -
adj. Prof - Anc. Langs & Eng.
State A & M. College of Texas -
